title: Succeeding as an introvert, building zero-to-one, and PMâ€™ing your career like a product | Deb Liu
key_insights: Always be learning - balance learning new skills with having impact to continuously grow
PM your career like a product - write a spec with milestones, skills, and success metrics
Growth is a game of inches - consistent small improvements compound better than seeking magic bullets
Introverts must learn to 'market' their work - reframe self-promotion as educating others about team impact
Most successful people are resilient - they turn stumbling blocks into stepping stones
30-60-90 day plans should focus on listening first, then aligning, then executing
Zero-to-one products need patience and minimal scrutiny to allow for iteration and failure
The most important career decision is who you marry - home life balance enables career success
topics_discussed: Building Facebook Marketplace from zero to 1 billion users
Creating Facebook's first mobile ad product
Strategies for introverts in extroverted workplaces
Zero-to-one product development within large companies
Growth as incremental optimization vs. big bets
Learning to handle failure and feedback
The role of coaching in professional development
Work-life balance and partner selection impact
Managing up and creating space for innovation
memorable_quotes: Some of the best PMs I have ever worked with are terrible PMs for their career. They just drift from job to job.
The most important career decision you make is who you marry. Is this person lifting you up or pushing you back?
Life is 10% what happens to you and 90% how you react to it.
frameworks_mentioned: Growth as game of inches methodology
summary: Former Facebook VP and current Ancestry CEO Deb Liu shares tactical career advice on building zero-to-one products, succeeding as an introvert, and treating your career like a product with intentional planning and resilience. She emphasizes that continuous learning, strategic career planning, and turning failures into growth opportunities are key to long-term success.
